name: ac4
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2
body: |- wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))

stmt.origin: axaci(s2, wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1))))))

body.origin:
|- wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))
-| wb(wac, wal(s2, wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))))

cumulated.origin:
|- wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))
-| wb(wac, wal(s2, wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))))

body.origin:
|- wb(wac, wal(s2, wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))))
-| diffss(s2, s0)
-| diffss(s2, s1)
-| diffss(s0, s1)

cumulated.origin:
|- wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))
-| diffss(s2, s0)
-| diffss(s2, s1)
-| diffss(s0, s1)

|- wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))
-| diffss(s2, s1)
-| diffss(s0, s1)
-| diffss(s0, s2)

|- wex(s0, wral(s1, cv(s2), wi(wne(cv(s1), emptycls), wcel(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(s1)))))
-| diffss(s0, s1)
-| diffss(s0, s2)
-| diffss(s1, s2)

comment: Equivalent of Axiom of Choice. We do not insist that ` f ` be a function. However, theorem ~ ac5 , derived from this one, shows that this form of the axiom does imply that at least one such set ` f ` whose existence we assert is in fact a function. Axiom of Choice of [TakeutiZaring] p. 83. Takeuti and Zaring call this "weak choice" in contrast to "strong choice" ` E. F A. z ( z =/= (/) -> ( F `` z ) e. z ) ` , which asserts the existence of a universal choice function but requires second-order quantification on (proper) class variable ` F ` and thus cannot be expressed in our first-order formalization. However, it has been shown that ZF plus strong choice is a conservative extension of ZF plus weak choice. See Ulrich Felgner, "Comparison of the axioms of local and universal choice", _Fundamenta Mathematica_, 71, 43-62 (1971). Weak choice can be strengthened in a different direction to choose from a collection of proper classes; see ~ ac6s5 . (Contributed by NM, 21-Jul-1996.)
